170 coaches have been hired to transport people to London, with activists set to travel from areas including Scotland, Wales, Cornwall and Lincolnshire.The full list of coach pick-up points&nbspcan be found on the People’s Vote website.David Lammy, the Labour MP and a leading supporter of the Final Say campaign, has said the march will be a “huge democratic moment for our country”.“On Saturday 19 October the people of the United Kingdom will come together to tell Boris Johnson loud and clear he must seek our consent before he inflicts his Brexit on our country,” he added.“Whether it’s a deal or no deal, the Brexit the prime minister is planning bears no relation to the promises made back in 2016 and it threatens immense harm to our economy, our prosperity, our young people and our United Kingdom.”The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by email“And that is why, on Saturday 19 October, vast numbers of people will gather in London for one of the biggest political demonstrations Britain has ever seen.”A spokesman for the People’s Vote campaign added: “The only way to break the deadlock in Parliament, legitimise the outcome and allow us all to talk about something else, is to give the people the final say.”Boris Johnson has repeatedly refused to hold a new public vote on Brexit, insisting that the UK will leave the EU on October 31, despite mounting pressure from Remain campaigners.Earlier this month, a poll&nbspshowed the public believes a fresh referendum would be a better way to break the Brexit deadlock than a general election.The YouGov survey, of 1,620 voters, found that only 35 per cent of voters support an election, while 40 per cent believe a Final Say referendum is the better way forward.Peter Kellner, the former president of YouGov, said: “It is clear that the public mood is hardening in favour of a people’s vote to decide whether Brexit should go ahead.&nbsp“As far as the general public is concerned, democracy is no longer served by simply enacting the result of the 2016 referendum.”Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, meanwhile, suggested that Britons would vote to stop Brexit if a second referendum went ahead.“All the polls since prime minister Johnson became prime minister suggest that’s what the British people actually want, but their political system isn’t able to give them that choice,” he said.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou story: Subscribe nowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘This challenges the claim that Britain has experienced a job creation miracle in recent years,’ says think tankBritain’s jobless rate is almost three times higher than official data suggests once “hidden unemployment” is included, according to new research.The report by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the Centre for Cities, a UK think tank, casts doubt on the apparent resilience of the UK labour market since the EU referendum in 2016.The authors define the “hidden” jobless as people who are not looking for a job because they believe no jobs are available where they live or because they have health issues or a disability. The researchers point to previous work by the OECD showing that some people with health issues or a disability would be able to work if arrangements such as flexible hours or remote work were an option.In contrast, UK government statisticians treat those two types of the “hidden” jobless as economically inactive rather than unemployed, without distinguishing why some people are not looking for work.“When the hidden unemployed are added to official unemployment statistics, the number of working-age jobless people not in education is estimated to jump from 4.6 per cent to 13.2 per cent,” the Centre for Cities said on Thursday.“This challenges the claim that Britain has experienced a job creation miracle in recent years.”Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson shake hands during a news conference after agreeing on a Brexit deal, in BrusselsA man walks his dog through the fallen leaves in Clarkes Gardens, Allerton in LiverpoolPolice officers carry away an activist as Extinction Rebellion protesters block a road with a caravan in central LondonQueen Elizabeth II sits with Prince Charles on the Sovereign's throne ahead of delivering the Queen's Speech at the State Opening of ParliamentGreat Britain's Joe Fraser competes on Parallel Bars during the World Gymnastics Championships in Stuttgart, Germany. title: eu enlargement emanuel macron albania north macedonia juncker
story: Subscribe nowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'Emotional'&nbsp2am meeting of EU leaders fails to open accession talks with Albania and&nbspNorth Macedonia&nbspEU enlargement plans were left stalled on Friday morning after Emmanuel Macron led opposition to opening accession talks with two new potential member states.North Macedonia and Albania want to start negotiations with the bloc after having been candidate countries since 2005 and 2014 respectively.The European Commission recommended in May this year that talks should begin with the two Western Balkan countries, but despite the overwhelming majority of&nbspmember states supporting the move, not all are convinced.&nbspA long meeting on Thursday night between the bloc's presidents and prime ministers, which diplomats described as emotional, ended at 2am with leaders agreeing no statement on the matter.French president Emmanuel Macron, standing relatively isolated, argued staunchly against opening talks with North Macedonia. He claimed that the EU's enlargement process was in general need of an overhaul. Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker described the move as historic error, while Council president Donald Tusk agreed it was&nbspa mistake.Macedonia officially changes name to North Macedonia to end disputeWhy is Macedonia considering changing its name?EU leaders have long said that if the former Yugoslav republic changed its name from Macedonia to end a decades-long dispute with Greece, its application could go ahead.The name change was politically costly for the country's government, which faced domestic opposition from nationalists. On Friday afternoon its foreign minister accused EU leaders of not being straightforward with us, but thanked those leaders who backed his country in the room.There was more widespread opposition on the European Council to opening talks with Albania, which some leaders argue has not made enough progress on reforms, including to the rule of law. Other than France,&nbspDenmark and the Netherlands raised concerns.A compromise plan proposed by the Netherlands' prime minister Mark Rutte to open talks with North Macedonia only failed, with EU leaders refusing to separate the two countries' bids from one another.A&nbspnumber of countries were reluctant regarding today's opening of negotiations, and France was part of them, Mr Macron confirmed.&nbspHe said the EU was struggling to take effective decisions with 28 members, and that&nbspbefore any effective enlargement we must reform ourselves.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe strongest supporters of admitting the two countries are Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic and Slovakia – the so-called Visegrad Four group. The states launched an unsuccessful diplomatic offensive ahead of the meeting to try and undermine the French veto.&nbspGermany's Angela Merkel was also supportive of opening talks, saying that she deplored the decision not to proceed.Unfortunately we were not able to reach agreement, she told a press conference on Friday after the meeting. We were not able to reach unanimity regarding that position. I very much deplore this fact.&nbspShe said North Macedonia had done a lot to meet conditions set by the bloc, adding: Albania too has made progress on the vetting process – the appointment of new judges is a far-reaching measure indeed that many countries in the Western Balkans have not yet got around to doing.&nbspThe chancellor continued: I always make the point that we have to be reliable when we make promises, when we set standards we have to be predictable in our responses instead of turning our backs on them and saying 'well, you've done quite well, but we've thought of something new'.I've always thought it was in Europe's interest to engage these countries in Europe. When you take a look at the map you get an idea of how important that is. We're talking about countries here that want to become members of the European Union.Speaking at the close of the summit, Council president Mr Tusk told reporters: The overwhelming majority wanted to open accession talks with North Macedonia and Albania, however such a decision requires unanimity and there was no unanimity yesterday.&nbspLet me be very clear –&nbspare not to blame for this and the Commission reports are also clear that both these countries did what they were asked to do.mBoth countries have the right to start negotiations as of today: they are ready. Unfortunately a few member states are not ready yet. This is why we did not manage to reach a positive decision. Personally I think it was a mistake but I will not comment on it further.Created with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A protester throws a tire on a fire to block the highway north of Beirut, Lebanon. story: Subscribe nowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Gerrit-Jan van Dorsten&nbspand man who rented farmhouse&nbsparrested on suspicion of ‘depriving people of their liberty’, say Dutch policeThe father of a family found by police in a secret basement below an isolated farmhouse was previously a member of a controversial religious sect, and may have tried to start a&nbspcult, Dutch media reports suggest.Gerrit-Jan van Dorsten, 68, is a former member of the Unification movement, which was set up by Sun Mung Moon in 1954 and whose followers are sometimes known as “Moonies”. Police confirmed they were investigating whether religious faith was involved in the family's alleged incarceration.Mr van Dorsten was arrested on Thursday on suspicion of “depriving people of their liberty, harming the health of others and money laundering”, Dutch police said in a statement.“We have reason to believe that the six people involved did not stay at the premises out of free will. We are investigating whether following a certain belief in life or faith has led to the living situation in which the people were found,” the police statement said, according to the Agence France-Presse&nbspnews agency.Mr van Dorsten’s six children were found by police after the eldest, a 25-year-old man, turned up at a local bar, drank five beers and told staff he needed help.Created He was reportedly also a former member of the Unification church, though the organisation has not confirmed this.Buitenhuizerweg in Ruinerwold, Drenthe (EPA)The Unification church said in a statement it was “deeply alarmed to hear of the family being held in inhumane conditions on a farmhouse in the Netherlands.” Mr van Dorsten was briefly a member of our movement in the mid-1980s, it said, but he left in 1987.The church's statement also revealed that Mr van Dorsten’s brother, Derek van Dorsten, remained “a long-time member” of the movement, and is quoted as saying “I have not heard from my brother since 1984”.It added: “In addition, we are unable to confirm any records of Mr Josef Brunner, the alleged captor, having ever been associated in any way with the Unification church.&nbspWe are grateful that the six victims in this tragedy are now under the care of the local authorities and pray they will be able to heal from their ordeal with time and professional help.”Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The 58-year-old is described as a furniture worker who also worked on yachts. He was regarded as “an absolute professional”, the report said.Willem Koetsier, a Unification Church member in Amsterdam, also told the paper that after Mr van Dorsten had left the group, he travelled to Germany where it lost track of him. Mr Koetsier said he thought the man “together with someone else” had since started their own cult.When police found Mr van Dorsten in the secret basement, he was apparently ill and in bed, having suffered a suspected stroke two years ago.&nbspAccording to Algemeen Dagblad, at the time Mr van Dorsten joined the Unification movement with his brother in the 1980s, he ascribed “supernatural powers” to himself.His wife and the mother of nine known children died in 2004.&nbspThree of Mr van-Dorsten’s children have come forward and said they left the family eight years ago.&nbspIt is possible he has even more children, the newspaper reports.Before the family moved to the farm in Ruinerwold, they had reportedly stayed at a caravan park where the children were filmed performing cult rituals including walking in circles. This apparently attracted unwanted attention, leading them to move to the secluded farm.Mr van Dorsten’s children, all aged over 18, are now in the care of the Dutch authorities.Want to bookmark your favourite articles and stories to read or reference later? Over 150 migrants made their way into Ceuta after storming a barbed-wire border fence with MoroccoTheir new report has outlined in shocking detail the extent to which Russia’s adoption system is open to abuse. It shows how a black market has been set up to off the most wretched in Russian society – using unregulated social media platforms to connect buyers to sellers via unscrupulous agents.&nbspThe exact scale of the illicit trade is unclear, but evidence points to an unhealthy demand. Every month, the most popular Russian search engine registers 85,000 searches of the term “buy a child” in Moscow alone.&nbspFor some, no doubt, it is a way to cut out three years of red tape and complicated adoption law. Often, the women involved are in desperate situations. But the opportunities for abuse of the most horrific kind are also obvious.&nbspThe prices quoted depend on the region and the child’s characteristics, the publication said. Non-Slavic children from the more underdeveloped regions of the Russian Federation are the least expensive. Slavs in Moscow and St Petersburg – the most. Court documents showed that in one case just 5,000 roubles (£60) swapped hands.&nbspThe journalists were offered well-worked schemes to get around social services checks.&nbspVladimir Putin to sign bill banning Americans from adopting RussianFor suspicious-looking men like the imagined Pavel Sarychev, the suggested route was getting the father of an abandoned baby to sign off on the adoption. For women, other options were suggested, including switching babies in the maternity ward under the watchless eyes of corrupted nurses.&nbspThere was little need to worry about being caught, agents said. With corrupted people in all parts of the system working for them, not even a DNA test would stop the trade going through.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailRussia’s adoption system has long been considered vulnerable by dent of corruption and the large number of orphans in its care (at one point the largest proportion in the world.)In recent years, authorities have introduced measures to improve children’s well-being and safety. But convictions for child trafficking remain rare – only three dozen such cases in the last eight years.&nbspCritics of the Kremlin’s approach to children’s safety also bring attention to the introduction of the infamous Dima Yakovlev law in 2013.&nbspNamed after a Russian child who died in the United States after his adoptive father accidentally left him in a car, the measures banned all adoptions to the United States. Hundreds of adoptions were cancelled at the last minute, with children and families left in the lurch. The Kremlin said it was only acting in the interests of children, but with terrible geopolitical relations in the background, they convinced few people.&nbspThe seemingly unfazed adoption agent quoted by The Insider emphasised this was one law he would never break.&nbspHe would never work with foreigners, he said – out of principle.&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: syria conflict turkey us foreign aid workers
story: Subscribe nowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.As Syrian regime troops advance into Kurdish territory, Turkish President Erdogan&nbspmaintains he&nbsp 'will never declare a ceasefire'The United Nations&nbsphas warned humanitarian aid could be cut off to war-torn areas of northern Syria impacting hundreds of thousands of people, after foreign aid workers were forced to flee the country as Turkey’s week-long offensive intensified.At least 71 civilians have been killed, and 300,000 have been displaced, since Ankara launched a controversial battle against Kurdish forces,&nbspaccording to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights,&nbspAn unknown number of Isis fighters and their relatives held in prisons and camps have also escaped amid the fighting.On Wednesday, ferocious battles raged in the Syrian border town of Ras Al-Ain with mortar rounds and rocket&nbspblasts&nbspheard from the adjacent Turkish city of Ceylanpinar.Outgunned, the Kurds have struck a deal with President Bashar al-Assad, whose soldiers advanced deep into Kurdish-controlled territory on Wednesday.Together with their Russian military allies, Syrian government troops entered the strategic border town of Kobani&nbspfor the first time in five years.Erdogan ‘green light’ for Syria invasionConcerned by the regime’s sudden territorial gains, and under intense Turkish fire, around 300 foreign aid workers were forced to abandon their posts. The Syrian government is hostile to foreign&nbspNGOs&nbspand many remain at risk of arrest.International aid and medical agencies, including Medicines Sans Frontieres, Save the Children, Mercy Corps and DanChurchAid, all released statements saying their intentional staff had&nbspto leave Syria, either partially or fully halting their activities there.The UN said this has disrupted the “supply change” of aid to much of northern Syria, which before the latest conflict was already home to nearly a million displaced people who depended on aid to survive.“Due to changes on the ground and insecurity some NGO partners have had to transfer international staff who were operating in the northeast out of the area, and others have had to temporarily suspend operations,” Hedinn Halldorsson from the agency in Damascus, told The Independent.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“Efforts continue to keep pipelines open to ensure the continuation of assistance,” he added.President Trump dispatched his top officials to Turkey on Wednesday for emergency talks to try to persuade Ankara to halt the offensive.&nbspCritics initially blamed Mr Trump for&nbsp”green-lighting” the incursion after he announced US troops would step aside and withdraw ahead of the imminent Turkish&nbspattack, abandoning his Kurdish allies who helped Washington defeat Isis.&nbspTrump angrily denies giving Turkey ‘green light’ for Syria invasionThe US has since punished Turkey with sanctions, including hiking up steel&nbsptariffs&nbspand pausing trade talks. A slew of countries including the UK has also imposed arms embargoes on Ankara, to little effect.&nbspBut despite the mounting pressure, Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan remained defiant, saying earlier: “We will never declare a ceasefire.”Back in Syria, meanwhile,&nbsp&nbspa rebel spokesman confirmed that the “operation is ongoing in&nbspRas&nbspal-Ain.” From the Turkish side of the border, ambulances could be seen in war-ravaged town racing away from the front,&nbsptowards hospitals.A briefing paper released by the Turkish government said the town centre of&nbspRas&nbspal-Ain&nbsphad been “cleared out of terrorists” along with 1,217 sq km of territory.Aid workers in Syria said international staff having to evacuate the country because of regime presence,&nbspwould only see the humanitarian crisis worsen.&nbspThe Kurdish Red Crescent (KRC)&nbspcalled the sudden withdrawal&nbspa “disaster” saying the KRC’s 1,000 or so staffers and volunteers were unable to shoulder the burden alone.“Coordination has almost collapsed since the international staffers had to leave. The burden was on them to secure cross border aid. We were also dependent on our partners to get funds, we need international doctors to support us,” the KRC’s Dr Sherwan Berry said.Turkey ‘effectively holding 50 US nuclear bombs hostage’ at air baseRussian soldiers filmed apparently moving into US Syria baseNine suspected Isis members escape from camp in Syria, says FranceMilitary veterans Tulsi Gabbard and Pete Buttigieg clash over SyriaHow Russia is filling the gap left by Trump’s withdrawal of US troops “We have such a load on our shoulders. We don’t have enough staff to man the hospitals, we lost a lot of clinics to shelling and bombing, we have 300,000 displaced people needing food, shelter, water and medical care. We are struggling to provide for them,” he added.He said that KRC ambulances had been targeted by Turkish strikes and several hospitals taken out of service because of the fighting.“Tens of thousands of internally displaced civilians are sleeping on the ground, lacking food, medicine and water,” he added.A senior foreign humanitarian professional, who asked not to be named for security reasons, said should the regime retain control of northeast Syria and the border&nbspit would be “catastrophic” as they would not be able to return.&nbsp“International aid agencies have been supporting hospitals in all the major towns and cities, they have been doing water tucking, bread distribution, rehabilitating schools, water stations and irrigations canals. title: queen speech britain brighter future
story: After all, it has no majority in Westminster, and is continually blocked by an unholy alliance of opposition MPs and Tory rebels putting political opportunism ahead of the national interest.It will, instead, be a Conservative Party manesto for a general election that surely cannot be far away.There will be a barrage of eye-catching crime fighting initiatives a promise of better-funded schools the hope of a world-class infrastructure to help Britain prosper and confirmation of greater investment in the NHS, thanks to the Brexit idend.It will be a tantalising glimpse of a brighter future, with long-neglected domestic issues finally getting attention.But voters must know these are things they can look forward to onlytwo things happen. The first is Brexit. The second is the ending of this rotten parliament. Neither can come soon enough.Expect hopeless puppet Jeremy Corbyn and those pulling his strings to try to block both.IT seems that “sorry” is not the hardest word, after all, for Anne Sacoolas.With the news that she no longer has diplomatic immunity over the car crash which killed Brit Harry Dunn, , in August, the US intelligence officer’s we broke her silence yesterday.Mrs Sacoolas’s lawyers said she wanted to meet Harry’s family “to express her deepest sympathy and apologies”.Understandably, Harry’s parents Charlotte Charles and Tim Dunn were less than impressed as they flew to America yesterday in search of justice, and Charlotte said: “As it’s nearly seven weeks now since we lost our boy, sorry just doesn’t cut it.”If the “devastated” Mrs Sacoolas truly does appreciate the pain Harry’s loss has caused, she will hopefully admit she was wrong to flee England,and let police continue their investigations.In the meantime, we hope a meeting with Harry’s parents will help them on the way towards some sort of closure.It’s the very least they deserve.IT will be another momentous week in British politics this week and yet it has all gone quiet on Brexit.Could it be that EU officials are too busy with their UK counterparts, working out the details of a deal its negotiators and their collaborators in our parliament said could not be done Let us hope that silence is golden.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we can thank tyrone mings for forcing uefa to confront racism in football at last
story: As a cacophony of monkey chants echoed around the stadium in Bulgaria on Monday night, Tyrone yelled at an assistant referee: “Hey, did you hear that ”The match should have been the greatest moment of the defender’s career.After years of struggle and sacrice, the -year-old was fulfilling his dream of pulling on the England shirt.As a lad, the Aston Villa star and his mum and three sisters lived in a homeless shelter for a year.And after being released by Southampton’s academy he played non-league football and made ends meet as a mortgage adviser.Instead, his first-ever international game descended into neo-Nazi chaos amid a cauldron of hate aimed at England’s black footballers.Much of the blame for this revolting event, which played out on primetime TV in front of millions, can be laid at the door of governing body Uefa, whose system for tackling racism was found desperately wanting.England’s players — who displayed astonishing calm and fortitude — have been let down time and again by a governing body that has allowed racism to fester.On Tuesday, Uefa president Aleksander Ceferin responded with tedious platitudes about how the “football family and governments” need to “wage war on the racists”.Yet it is his lucrative competition which is providing primetime TV exposure for these fascists.Uefa’s three-step protocol was pathetically inadequate.It states that after first hearing abuse, the referee will arrange for a warning announcement to fans to be broadcast.If it continues, the second step is for the referee to suspend the match for around ten minutes and take the players off the pitch while a second warning is made.If that fails when the game is restarted then the match is abandoned.In the end, this was only partly enacted as England decided not to come off.The flimsy rules begged the question: How many times do you need to experience a chorus of monkey chants before it’s wrong Bulgaria’s coach Krasimir Balakov later claimed he didn’t hear anything — but millions at home could hear and see the abuse that rained down for much of the half.Inside the ground, England fans sang: “You racist b******s, you know what you are.”Many fans on social media called for the England players to walk off.If England had walked off without Uefa permission, it would have sent reverberations across the world. But, perversely, it may have also cost them the game.There are not yet specic punishments in place for breaking the racism protocol but Uefa’s Disciplinary Regulations  state: “If a match cannot take place or cannot be played in full, the member association or club responsible forfeits the match.”So it could have been perceived as a home win for racism and defeat for England.Uefa’s woefully inadequate response to a litany of previous racist incidents meant it was left up to Tyrone to make a call.Cool-headed England manager Gareth Southgate later said all his players wanted to carry on.If Uefa bosses had spines, they should have abandoned the game and given the points to England.Players should be able to walk out on a game where mass racism is taking place without risk of forfeiting the match. If nations such as Bulgaria can’t police and steward racist fans, then Uefa should force them to play behind closed doors or exclude them from tournaments until they can.In the build-up to the game, the Bulgarians pointed out the English could hardly occupy the moral high ground.There have been a number of reports of players being racially abused at games here this year and stars are regularly subjected to racism on social media.I have reported on England games for The Sun for the past  years and the dedicated fans are a friendly and welcoming bunch.Most use the opportunity of foreign games for sight-seeing and immersing themselves in local culture.Yet a “stag do” following of younger yobbish fans attaches themselves to Three Lions away games in party destinations such as Amsterdam, Porto and Prague.Booze and drugs are swilled down and continental squares echo to the sound of Ten German Bombers and splintering glass.A minority of fans it may be, but they are still intimidating to locals and families. We have our own house to get in order, too.After the final whistle Tyrone stated that he believed England’s collective decision to stay on was the correct one, saying he was “proud of how we dealt with it”.Dignied in stark contrast to the far-Right nasties who had hounded him.His cry of “Hey, did you hear that ” must surely now be acted upon in football’s corridors of power.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits on universal credit could have work allowance raised again new dwp minister reveals
story: Thérèse Coffey, who took over from Amber Rudd as the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, said that a benefits boost might be on the cards.The news would be a huge win for The Suns Make Universal Credit campaign, where we have been demanding Brits get to keep more of their own cash.She told MPs on the DWP committee this morning: I think it’s important that we need to see what the outcomes are that we want.So consideration about things like increasing the work allowance on Universal Credit before the taper kicks in - trying to do what we can about that element as well.That sort of analysis is ongoing.Last year the Chancellor announced a £ hike to the personal allowance, allowing Brits on Universal Credit to keep an extra £ a year.But she appeared to back away from making any changes to the five-week wait for cash on the six-in-one benefits system, saying that Brits applying for an advance was working well.However, the new DWP minister refused to say whether the benefits freeze would definitely end in April .It was widely expected that ministers would ditch the freeze on working age benefits from next year.The freeze was only meant to be in place for four years, and wasnt expected to be renewed.Ms Coffeys predecessor Amber Rudd had said she was making the case to the Chancellor for finally giving Brits a hike to their cash.The new DWP boss said she could not give a definitive outcome on it yet.Im in discussions with Treasury about this, but until I get the analysis which is due before the end of the month, then I won’t be in a position to say exactly what we’ll do on every single product line, she said today.She said the Government was looking carefully about what it could do with benefits.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.The new Secretary of State gave a staunch defence of Universal Credit today, arguing that her Suffolk constituents would give it a . out of ten.She also refused to accept there was a link between the benefit cap and child poverty.And the Permanent Secretary Peter Schofield told MPs that there were , cases of suspected Universal Credit fraud being investigated after reports of scams.

story: The “People’s Vote” mob have repeatedly told the world that Britain has changed its mind and is itching to reverse Brexit. title: brits ditching couch potato lifestyle
story: Some .million in England achieved the recommended  minutes of moderate exercise a week in the past year.A new low of .million were classed as inactive for failing to complete even half an hour a week.Health chiefs say the fitness revolution has been largely driven by the elderly taking up running and joining gyms.A greater number of women are also joining fitness centres.Sport England, a public body that promotes exercise, quizzed , people aged  and over.The number in England meeting official guidelines has risen by more than a million since  to hit a record high.EXERCISING before breakfast burns twice as much fat as training after, a study found.It may also cut the risk of Type  diabetes and heart disease.Scientists analysed data on  fat men who were put through a six- week training regime.Half ate before cycling on a stationary bike and half after. Scientists at Bath and Birmingham universities found the eat later group burnt more fat and were “dramatically” healthier.There has also been a fall of , in the number classied as inactive over the same period.The wealthy are more likely to be active than poorer people, and men more than women – although the gap is closing.There are , more active adults aged  and over and , fewer inactive in this age group in the past year alone.Walking remains the most popular activity. title: glass wine day worse binge drinking
story: Frequent but minimal drinkers are more likely to develop atrial fibrillation — irregular heartbeat.It can cause shortness of breath and chest pains, and raise the risk of a stroke five-fold.Scientists in South Korea warned this could be dangerous after studying the drinking habits of almost ten million people.They asked the participants, who underwent a national health check-up in , how many times they indulged per week, the amount of alcohol in each session, and the amount overall.The participants were followed up until  to seethey had a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation.And the researchers found that the risk of atrial fibrillation increased by eight per cent for every drink over a week, but the number of sessions was the strongest risk factor.And those who drank every day had a  per cent higher risk than those who consumed alcohol twice a week.Dr Jong-Il Choi, leader of the Korean study, said the heart condition has “dreadful complications” that could wreck lives.He said: Our study suggests that frequent drinking is more dangerous than infrequent binge drinking with regard to atrial fibrillation.The number of drinking sessions was related to atrial fibrillation onset regardless of age and sex.Repeated episodes of atrial fibrillation triggered by alcohol may lead to overt disease.In addition, drinking can provoke sleep disturbance which is a known risk factor for atrial fibrillation.On the other hand, binge drinking did not show any clear link with new-onset atrial fibrillation, according to the study published in the journal EP Europace.Dr Choi said people should cut the frequency and amount they drink.He said: Preventing atrial fibrillation itself, rather than its complications, should be our first priority.Alcohol consumption is probably the most easily modiable risk factor.To prevent new-onset atrial fibrillation, both the frequency and weekly amount of alcohol consumption should be reduced.A normal heart rate should be regular and between  and  beats a minute when youre resting.In atrial fibrillation, the heart rate is irregular and can sometimes be very fast.In some cases, it can be considerably higher than  beats a minute.This can cause problems including dizziness, shortness of breath and tiredness.You may be aware of noticeable heart palpitations, where your heart feels like its pounding, fluttering or beating irregularly, often for a few seconds or, in some cases, a few minutes.Sometimes atrial fibrillation does not cause any symptoms and a person who has it is completely unaware that their heart rate is irregular.Source: NHSThe study found that drinking every day was the riskiest, while drinking once a week was the least risky.British Heart Foundation cardiologist Dr Sonya Babu-Narayan said the study has limitations.She said: The people participating only reported how much and how often they drank alcohol once, yet their habits could have changed over time.Furthermore, the study cannot confirmand how alcohol habits increase the risk of AF.If you choose to drink alcohol, it’s important to stay within the current UK guidelines of no more than  units a week, keeping some days alcohol free.AF is the most common heart rhythm disturbance, affecting around one million people in the UK, and .million in the US. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we title: toxic chemicals baby food study
story: Poisonous chemicals such as lead and arsenic were found in many of the baby foods tested, along with cadmium and mercury.Scientists believe increased exposure to such toxins can erode a childs developing brain, damaging their IQ.The report, released Thursday, was put together by the US-based group Healthy Babies Bright Future, a collection of nonprofits and doctors who look to prevent early childhood exposure to neurotoxins.Overall,  foods were tested from  producers, with  per cent of products containing all four metals tested for.According to the findings,  per cent of products contained lead,  per cent contained arsenic,  per cent contained cadmium, and  per cent contained mercury.Dr Philip Landrigan, a pediatrician and director of the global public health program at Boston College, said in a statement: Exposures in early le are especially dangerous.The cumulative impact of exposures is what makes this a signicant concern that demands action.Exposure to such toxins can alter a babys developing brain and erode a childs IQ, the study warned, with the impact on a babys brain increasing with exposure.Some of the worst culprits mentioned in the study were sweet potatoes and fruit juices.Rice-based products – such as rice cereal, rice dishes and rice-based snacks – were listed as the most toxic foods for babies.These findings come after a Abt Associates, a nationally recognised toxicology and economic research firm in the US, estimated that lead and arsenic found in rice-based foods made up for around one-fth of the  million IQ points that are lost by children before the age of two.A previous study by the Food and Drug Organization also found that one or more of the four metals tested for by Health Babies Bright Futures study was found in  of the  types of baby food it tested.Healthy Babies Bright Futures hopes its finding will encourage the US Food and Drug Administration to set health-based limits on trace chemicals, helping to protect babies brains from exposure through meals.Thursdays report states that of  of  baby food types tested, there is no FDA guidance on safe limits for toxic heavy metals.Though experts agree that no level of lead is safe, one in five baby foods tested had more than  times the -ppb limit of lead that is endorsed by public health advocates.The report also stated that  per cent of the risk to babies brains comes from  products that are consumed by children under the age of two – including grape and apple juice, fruit yogurt, and soft cereal bars.Such concerns over the health risks tied to the USs baby food market have seen organic baby sales boom during recent years – yet the report does still warn about organic standards not addressing the risks of neurotoxins.By , it is expected that the global organic baby food market could reach . billion – an increase from . billion in .To protect the babies of tomorrow, the food companies and the FDA need to step up and do more.Physicians have claimed the likes of salmon, pureed vegetables and avocados are safe for babies.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: manchester airport meet greet couples mercedes
story: Lisa Hook and Antony Smith paid £ to leave their car near to Manchester Airport while they went on a two-week holiday to Turkey.But when they ed on October , the firm Meet and Greet Manchester Airport Services Ltd said they couldnt find their car.Lisa and Antony, from Barnsley, got a taxi to the firms site in Styal and were shocked by the state of the fields where cars are left.Photographs show scores of vehicles parked in muddy, rutted fields.The car park is not affiliated with Manchester Airport.Despite two trips to the site and numerous phone calls, the firm said they were unable to locate the car.Police confirmed the couples silver Mercedes C-class  CDI AMG sport edition had been reported as stolen.Lisa, a warehouse operator, and Antony, a wagon driver, had saved for years for the car and say it is worth around £,.Theyd booked the meet and greet parking via a website called Fly Park Plus.Lisa, , told Manchester Evening News: It has been so stressful.We followed all of the instructions we were given on the booking email.On the way out we called the number half-an-hour before we arrived, as instructed, and dropped the car off with one of their drivers.He knew our names and our booking. He took it and we assumed it would be ed to us when we came back.We rang after wed landed and they said they couldnt find the car.There were a lot of phone calls back and forth - all in the early hours of the morning.First they were saying they couldnt find the car, then they couldnt locate the keys and then they started denying we had ever left our car with them.We went to the police at the airport and explained what had happened.They gave us the address to head up to the car park in Styal. When we got there the women who we had spoken to on the phone started saying they werent the company wed booked with.At one point she askedwe were sure wed dropped it off at the right place.It was ridiculous. title: japan imports ebola tokyo 2020 olympics
story: Last month, Japanese officials obtained the infectious virus along with four other fatal pathogens in preparation for next summer’s event.This is the first time ever viruses rated biosafety-level-- the most dangerous rating – have been allowed to enter Japan.The country will be storing the pathogens at the Japanese National Institute of Infectious Diseases , the only facility able to operate at that level.According to reports, the other killer bugs are Marburg virus, Lassa virus, the viruses that cause South American haemorrhagic fever and Crimean–Congo haemorrhagic fever.Researchers will use the pathogens to validate tests under development.Experts within the science community have welcomed the move as it will boost Japan’s ability to handle infectious diseases, Nature.It will also help authorities prepare against the threat of a bioterror attack during the Olympics.Masayuki Saijo, director of the NIID department said: This is a landmark time, a landmark event.”However, not everyone is happy.Built in , the NIID’s laboratory in Musashimurayama, Tokyo, has never operated at a BSL- level before because of opposition from locals.Some residents have told Japanese media that authorities are using the Olympics as a pretext to import the killer viruses.Yet, Elke Mühlberger, a microbiologist at Boston University, has praised the move highlighting the ongoing Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.She said: “A report of an Ebola virus infection during the Olympics could have devastating consequencesthe emergency responses were not professional.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: obesity clogs lung fat asthma
story: It has long been known that tubby people are at greater risk of the potentially killer breathing condition.Now for the first time, scientists have shown carrying too many pounds leads to fatty tissue accumulating in airway walls.Researchers based in Australia suggest that fat deposits narrowing the airways could be a reason behind this previously unexplained increased risk.The peer-review study published in the European Respiratory Journal, which is thought to be the first of its kind, found that excess fatty tissue changes the structure of peoples airways.Researchers from Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, Perth, and the University of Western Australia used samples from  people and examined , airways.They looked at the lungs of people who had died from asthma, as well as asthma sufferers who had died from other causes and a group of those without asthma to evaluate the impact of BMI on the airways.Using the tissue samples and dyes, they microscopically examined the amount of fat in the lung tissue and compared that with the persons BMI and medical history.The researchers discovered a correlation between the amount of fat in the lungs and body weight.It was known that fat accumulates around other organs including the liver, but there had previously been no research into the impact of excess fat on the airways.Dr Peter Noble, associate professor at the University of Western Australia in Perth and co-author of the study, said: Being overweight or obese has already been linked to having asthma or having worse asthma symptoms.Researchers have suggested that the link might be explained by the direct pressure of excess weight on the lungs or by a general increase in inflammation created by excess weight.This study suggests that another mechanism is also at play. Weve found that excess fat accumulates in the airway walls where it takes up space and seems to increase inflammation within the lungs.We think this is causing a thickening of the airways that limits the flow of air in and out of the lungs, and that could at least partly explain an increase in asthma symptoms.According to the NHS, the main symptoms of asthma are:Although the above symptoms can have a number of causes, they are likely signs of asthmathey happen regularly and keep coming back, are worse at night or early morning, or seem to be in response to an allergen.The severity of the above symptoms can y between dferent people.When these symptoms suddenly worsen temporarily, it is known as an asthma attack.Asthma attacks can be caused by allergens, such as animal fur or pollen, cold air, exercise, chest infections or other irritants - such as cigarette smoke.Allergies and asthma often go together.Asthma caused by an allergic reaction is known as allergic asthma.There are now hopes that this initial finding will now lead to further studies on the relationship between asthma and high BMIs as well as research into whether the effects can be reversed by weight loss.European Respiratory Society president Professor Thierry Troosters, who was not involved in the study, said: This is an important finding on the relationship between body weight and respiratory disease because it shows how being overweight or obese might be making symptoms worse for people with asthma.This goes beyond the simple observation that patients with obesity need to breathe more with activity and exercise hence adding to their ventilatory burden. The observation points at true airway changes that are associated with obesity.Emma Rubach, Head of Health Advice at Asthma UK, said: “This study adds to growing evidence thatyou are overweight it can make your asthma symptoms worse.“This is because getting active boosts your lung power and reduces breathlessness.“You don’t need to run a marathon to be active with asthma, even doing gentle activity like gardening or going for a walk could improve your asthma symptoms.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Sea cadets march through London this weekend in the annual Trafalgar Day parade, to mark Nelsons defeat of the French and Spanish in . Heres the route and advice on where to watch.To commemorate the Battle of Trafalgar, the Trafalgar Day Parade starts in London at am on Sunday, October , and ends at pm.On October  , Admiral Lord Nelson defeated the French and Spanish fleets of Cape Trafalgar in South West Spain and lost his own le in the battle.This Sunday will see  sea cadets, aged from -, from across the UK, converge upon Horse Guards Parade to start the parade at am.On Facebook, Sea Cadets UK explained that due to the Extinction Rebellion protests in central London we are unable to guarantee the use of Trafalgar Square for Sundays National Trafalgar Day commemorations.Weve taken the decision to move the parade to Horse Guards Parade, just a short distance away.Were delighted that cadets will still get the chance to march in central London, especially in formation down the Mall towards Buckingham Palace. The Lord Mayor of Westminster will attend the event, which includes a mass band display event as well as a guard and colour party fall-in.Wreaths will be laid after the Last Post Reveille is played.Following an inspection, the sea cadets will leave Horse Guards Parade and march up Horse Guards Road, turning left onto The Mall.At Wellington Barracks, an address will be given by the Commandant General of the Royal Marines, Major General Matt Holmes.A spokesperson for Sea Cadets UK recommended that the best vantage points include The Mall, all the way to Buckingham Palace, and on Horse Guards Parade itself.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman lived van pet rats gnawed belongings
story: The animal lover, named only as Carla, started out living with just two pet rodents on a road in San Diego.But the pair quickly bred, and their offspring borrowed into the vans upholstery, door , dashboard, and engine wiring.Rats can give birth every four weeks and produce up to a dozen pups in each litter.The San Diego Human Society received several complaints about the situation from local shops when the rats began venturing out of the van.Capt. Danee Cook said officials realised right away the situation was signicant after arriving to inspect the van on October .They could tell immediately that it was a huge amount [of rats],” he said.They were living out of the van, coming and going.This was not a cruelty case, this was a relinquishment, an owner asking for help.She was feeding all of them, had water for all of them.This didn’t meet the standards of hoarding.Carla agreed to give the rats up and officers began the job of retrieving them from every crevice of the van.A total of around  rats, mostly babies, were collected, of which  are currently ready for adoption.The Human Society is offering them up for for two.Carla had reportedly been at risk of losing her job at a nearby branch of the Circle K supermarket because of the rats.She was unable to move the van because it had broken down, but a GoFundMe page was set up to cover the cost of having it towed to a spot away from the shops.The page raised , , the remainder of which will go towards buying Carla a new van.

title: big ben facts tall elizabeth tower when how time
story: The Elizabeth Tower - home to the bells - has been keeping for  years this year. Heres the lowdown on the iconic tower.It is thought that the bell was originally to be called Royal Victoria in honour of Queen Victoria but Londoners started calling the bell Big Ben and the name stuck.The origin of the nickname remains the subject of some debate.It is believed Big Ben was named after Sir Benjamin Hall, who oversaw the installation of the Great Bell.Others believe the bell was named after boxer Ben Caunt, who was the English Heavyweight Champion.Formerly known as the Clock Tower, the structure was renamed the Elizabeth Tower in  in honour of the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee in .But it is the bell within the tower that is referred to as Big Ben.Standing at  feet high, the tower is the focal point of the Grade I-listed Palace of Westminster, which forms part of a UNESCO World Heritage site.The Elizabeth Tower is also the most photographed building in the UK.And now the clocks cogs and hands, as well as the four dials, will be removed, cleaned up and repaired as part of the work.Because the clock mechanism will be temporarily out of action, a modern electric motor will drive the clock hands until the clock is reinstated.Completed in , the tower was designed by architects Charles Barry and Augustus Welby Pugin and took  years to build.Its construction required  cubic metres of brick and  cubic metres of stone.It began telling time on May , .Big Ben chimed for the first time on July , .The -tonne Great Bell was last stopped for maintenance in  and before that was halted for two years in  for refurbishment.The current restoration project will mark the longest period of silence for the bell.However, it will still sound on big occasions such as New Years Day and Remembrance Sunday.Big Ben houses four clocks and their dials are set in an iron frame that is  feet in diameter.On each side,  shards of opal class make up the clock face.The copper minute hands are  feet long as tall - as a double decker bus - these famous dials have kept London running on time.It chimes every hour on the hour to the note of E and also houses bells that chime every quarter-hour - their strikes are controlled by the intricate ticking mechanism at the heart of the tower.There are huge weights on long cables that attach to each train of gears.Their rotation is regulated by the escapement and the swinging pendulum.It keeps the clock accurate to within one second.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: big ben silent bongs back remembrance sunday christmas new year
story: Heres everything you need to know about the famous Westminster clock tower, including how its been keeping time for  years as of May , .Completed in , the tower was designed by architects Charles Barry and Augustus Welby Pugin and took  years to build.Its construction required  cubic metres of brick and  cubic metres of stone.It began telling time on May , .Big Ben chimed for the first time on July , .The -tonne Great Bell was last stopped for maintenance in  and before that was halted for two years in  for refurbishment.The current restoration project will mark the longest period of silence for the bell.However, it will still sound on big occasions such as New Years Day and Remembrance Sunday.Londons most iconic landmark, and the most photographed building in Britain, could do with a bit of a facelt.The Elizabeth Tower, home to the Big Ben bell, is undergoing crucial conservation work.With scaffolding already covering much of the tower, repairs have started on the ancient building to ensure it can be preserved for future generations - and be made more energy efficient.Part of this renovation includes work on the . tonne Great Bell, known to many people as Big Ben.To protect the workers tinkering with the Victorian clockwork mechanism behind the famous bongs, the bell has been disconnected from the clock while work is ongoing.There were fears that the bells hourly bongs, and the chimes which take place every  minutes, would damage workers hearing and risk startling them on the job.As such, the bells striking mechanism has been locked in place, to prevent any regular bonging throughout the renovation process.However, the clock still tells the time with the help of an electric motor, which is being used while the main mechanism is being restored.Big Bens striking mechanism was locked on Monday, August  - with a crowd of , gathering to hear the last bongs at noon.The renovation work is expected to last for four years, meaning the there will be no regular bongs until .However, the much-loved bell will still sound for important events like New Years Eve and Remembrance Sunday.Officials admitted the clock might be slightly wrong after weeks of inactivity and it will need adjusting.So they will reconnect the mechanism a couple of days early to ensure Big Ben rings out at exactly am when royals, ministers and veterans gather at the Cenotaph.The House of Commons said the chimes will sound from am tomorrow to pm on Sunday November .The same issue is predicted when the bells are reconnected on December  ahead of its Christmas and New Year chiming.The bells will fall silent again at pm on January .There was widespread criticism from the media, the public and politicians over plans to bring  years of almost unbroken bonging to an end.Members of Parliament claim they didnt know that the bell would be silent for four years when they signed off on the renovation work.After criticism from MPs, including PM Theresa May, parliamentary authorities announced the plan for Big Ben to fall silent for four years was under review.And I hope that the speaker, as the chairman of the House of Commons commission, will look into this urgently so that we can ensure that we can continue to hear Big Ben through those four years.But protests against the plans came too late to have an effect, with many politicians wading in just days before the work was due to begin.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal angela merkel eu extension
story: The French President clashed with his Brussels ally by saying the EU will “stick to the deadline of October ”.The claim comes after the German Chancellor made it clear to fellow leaders they could not pretend an extension would not be offered,requested by Parliament.But Mr Macron said: “That being said, Im not trying to read the future but I do not think we shall grant any further delay.I believe it is now time to put an end to these negotiations and work on the future relationship and put an end to what is currently ongoing.Like I said, there shall be no delay unless there are some major changes.The European Commission President said yesterday: “He [Boris Johnson] and myself dont think its possible to give another prolongation. There will be no other.“We have a deal so why should we have a prolongation.”But its not up to Mr Juncker, its up to the EU membersthey want another extension. All of them need to unanimously agree for the green light to go ahead.The conversation between EU leaders took place shortly before they publicly backed Mr Johnson’s deal,claimed.Ms Merkel then instructed the PM not to tell the press that an extension would be ruled out.After Boris left the private meeting, certain EU bosses – including Luxembourg’s Xavier Bettel and Malta’s Joseph Muscat – said they did not have the appetite for another Brexit delay.Ms Merkel later told reporters: “We have not been focusing on the question today,or when. It’s a free decision to be taken by the British parliament.”EU Council President Donald Tusk backed Ms Merkel’s message and told a press conference that member states would consider the request.He told said: “If there is a request for an extension, I will contact member states to see how to react.”Boris is now embarking on a -hour charm offensive today to sell his “great new” Brexit deal.He faces a race against time ahead of Saturday’s showdown in the Commons after the DUP vowed to vote down his agreement.Hardline Tory Brexiteers are letting the PM sweat over whether they will vote his Brexit plan – but the government is confident they can win the majority of the  ‘Spartans’ round.The PM has also left the door open to restoring the whip to the  ex-Tory MPs he sacked last month for backing the Brexit-delaying Benn Act in another bid to boost his numbers.However, he also needs the support of Labour Brexiteers - with  ready to enrage Jeremy Corbyn by pushing the deal through.The Labour rebels will back Borishe publishes a bill before Saturday that would offer EU-style protection to workers’ rights.“ButBoris can write all these things onto the face of a bill, and bring that bill forward pronto, we can vote for it.”

title: mum trolled after sharing post about feeding bread to starving ducks
story: Families have been urged to feed the ducks amid a hunger crisis after posters appeared in parks in Derbyshire.The poster appeared in the Pavilion Gardens in Buxton, Derbyshire, but the parks managers insisted they were not responsible.The mysterious signs encourage people to help the ducks – but the posters stirred up confusion about whether or not it is harmful.A mum who put a photo of the sign on Facebook was inundated with messages demanding she remove her post.Louisa Taylor said: “I honestly thought I was doing a good deed.I have two young children so I really dont need the stress of it all.The photo - which was taken by one of Ms Taylors friends - has appeared in thousands of Facebook timelines after being posted online.It reads: Please feed us again, especially in the winter!Everyone has stopped feeding us because they wrongly think bread will make us poorly and now some of us are dying of starvation without your bread.It continues: Yes, its not the healthiest for us but nothing in our bellies will kill us!One punter said: How do people in this day and age still find it so dficult to do something as simple as feed ducks something other than bread!Another said: Generations of people have fed ducks stale bread for years!! I see no decline in the duck population, just bloody feed them.One woman even claimed she and her husband were publicly told off by a stranger for feeding bread to ducks.The woman who originally took the photo did not want to be named in this story because she feared a backlash for spreading incorrect information.She said: There had been signs up the year before saying you cant feed bread to the ducks anymore, but then this sign was saying the ducks were dying and starving and I thought oh dear.Ive got no idea whos put it up. It was only up for a few days and I havent seen it since.Its quite confusing. If the advice is wrong then I dont really want to be responsible for putting it out there.Tony Whitehead, of The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds , said: Just like us, birds need a ied diet to stay healthy.Although ducks and swans can digest all types of bread, too much can leave them feeling full without giving them all of the important vitamins, minerals and nutrients they need.So, although bread isnt harmful, our advice is to only feed small amounts to birds.Peter Morris, of the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust, said bread was fine for water birds as long as it only forms a small part of their diet.But moderation is hard to judge when other well-meaning people may also be feeding bread to the same birds at other times.

title: brit teacher relives petrol station explosion which left her unrecognisable
story: Zoe Eleftheriou, , from Medway, Kent, and Abigail Alexander, , from Ohio, USA, are lucky to be alive after suffering horric injuries in the blast which was captured on a dashcam video in Cambodia, in August.The pair were riding a motorcycle together past an LPG gas station in Siem Reap when it suddenly exploded - blowing them off the bike and causing severe burns.Zoe was moved to a hospital in Bangkok, Thailand, while Abigail was treated at the Royal Phnom Penh Hospital.The English teacher lost her eyebrows and suffered severe facial bruises in the blast which claimed three lives and left another dozen badly injured.Reliving her ordeal, Zoe said: The receptionist did not recognise me and I had been working there for six months.I was burning and all I wanted was ice and I said I need it now.Zoe suffered  per cent fourth and fth degree burns all over her body, badly affecting her left leg, hands and face.It was thought she would have to spend at least two months in a burns treatment hospital in Bangkok but after gradually coming off the ventilator she was allowed to fly home to Kent.She said: At the moment, I have pink, red, white and brown skin and some sexy marks on my feet where my flip-flops had been.They say pigmentation can take six months or up to two years to heal.It sounds horrible, but I was ing as a vegetable. I cant put weight on my foot, so I cant walk yet.Its great at the age of  that I am no longer in nappies and using a bed-pan.The first time I saw my face, I did not like it. I had no eyebrows or lashes and had lost my long hair. It was bright red, apple red, fire red.I have had tremendous support from family and friends.I dont know why at Heathrow they wanted to see my passport because I dont look anything like my passport photo.Zoes mother, Mary, said at the time of the blast: I arrived beside Zoe to find her bandaged back up and still with tubes down her throat.It was explained they were still there because of the swelling on her neck and the rest of her body.She is able to nod and shake her head to questions or write letters in the air with her bandaged hands but trying to guess what she is saying is pretty hard.Zoe is a fighter and will pull though this so please keep her and Abbey in your prayers.Zoe added: One seven year old said You are still the same Zoe, you just look a little dferent.And luckily, her medical bills of £, were covered by a £ travel insurance policy.Abbey faces a similar treatment bill - but had no cover.She was paid only £, by the LPG station boss, while Zoe is still battling for compensation.After her experience, she cannot stress enough the importance to fellow travellers of getting full travel insurance.She said: It was on my mums tick list before I went anywhere. You might say I dont need it, but you do.Dashcam footage from a car shows the huge burst or orange flames hitting passing motorcycle riders who were knocked to the ground from the force of the explosion.A tanker truck containing , litres of the liquid fuel was transferring the gas to a storage tank behind the unlicensed LPG gas station when it ignited.Brigadier General Phing Sambath, deputy police chief of Siem Reap province, said  fire trucks with  tanks of water were used to extinguish the blaze.He said: A total of  people, including police officers, guards, and female westerners, were wounded in the blast.The two foreigners, whose nationalities are not identied, had their skins burned while passing through the gas station when the tank exploded.The police are gathering evidence and searching for the owner of the gas station who was not at the shop when officers arrived to begin investigation.He added: The transfer was done improperly and some gas leaked. The station owner asked the staff to turn off the electricity and there was a sudden.

title: brexit deal amendments explained full
story: NewsBrexit deal amendments explained: full list of bids to change Boris Johnsons dealRemain MPs have put a plan to get a second referendum on hold - but other amendments could go throughShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMPs can keep tabling amendments right up until tomorrow "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnsonaposs new deal will be tested when MPs hold a special Saturday sitting of the House of Commons. Mr Johnson ed to London following dinner on Thursday evening in Brussels, skipping day two of the summit as he attempted to shore up support. Any hope of an easy passage was dashed after the DUP rubbished the fresh agreement. But as well as debating the new deal MPs will also try and amend the legislation. So far they have unveiled three amendments to the deal. But ious groups are furiously drafting further changes they want to table. The most signicant is by ex-Tory Sir Oliver Letwin. It would refuse to approve Boris Johnsonaposs deal in final form tomorrow.  Thataposs because of fears that eventhe deal is approved tomorrow, a no-deal Brexit could still happen by accident. This is a bit tricky to explain - but basically, tomorrow isnapost the final vote on the Brexit deal.MPs will get loads more votes on something called the EU Withdrawal Bill, which is an instrument used to pass the deal formally into law. The problem is thatthe Bill gets stuck or disputed, the aposBenn Actapos - which forces the PM to seek a delay to Brexitthereaposs no deal - will have lapsed because it has an October  deadline.  Sir Oliver fears that,the Withdrawal Bill somehow gets snarled up after October , we could be left in legal limbo on October .So his amendment would decline to approve the Brexit deal unless and until every single vote on the legislation is safely passed. The cross-party amendment has support from Labouraposs Hilary Benn, Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson, Plaid Cymruaposs Liz Saville Roberts and the SNPaposs Stephen Gethins. Meanwhile, two SNP amendments will also call for a general election and revoking Article  to cancel Brexit - but itaposs unclear whether they will even get called. Speaker John Bercow has the final say over what reaches the floor of the Commons.  Meanwhile a bid to use Saturdayaposs historic session to secure a second referendum is currently on hold - with campaigners looking to next week instead. Remain MPs had planned to tack on a bid to get a second bill. Yesterday they changed the rules surrounding Saturdayaposs sitting in order to leave open the possibility of both Letwinaposs amendment and one on a public vote. But they continued with frantic discussions to try and gameplay the most effective time to bring forward the vote. Boris Johnson finally agreed a Brexit deal with the EU on  October  - though it stills need approval from MPs and could face a narrow defeat. The -page list of amendments keeps a transition period up to  December  and the £bn orce bill. But it scraps the Irish backstop, an insurance policy designed at preventing a hard border between Northern Ireland the Republic. In the backstopaposs place would effectively be apostwo bordersapos in a hybrid system:Northern Ireland and Britain would share a customs territory - technically forcing customs checks on goods crossing the -mile border with the Republic. But in practice, to avoid checks at the border, the checks will instead happen when goods reach Northern Ireland on the island of Ireland. Critics say this puts checks across the Irish Sea - more of this below.  Northern Ireland and the Republic would share some EU single market rules - forcing checks on manufactured and agricultural products crossing the Irish Sea.The Northern Ireland Assembly - known as Stormont - will get a vote every four years on whether to let EU law continue. But this vote could be passed by a simple majority - denying the DUP a veto on staying under EU laws long-term. For a full explainer click here.
